newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares set high, seen extending gains.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares set high, seen extending gains.

text.p: Polish shares on Thursday set a third consecutive 33-month high in heavy trade and post-fixing buying was seen pushing them to another high on Friday, but analysts said a profit-taking correction was likely next week.
The bourse has risen 23 percent since December 10.

"After today's session I believe there might be more growth tomorrow, but I think next week investors will start taking profits after such a surge," said Maciej Matusiak, an analyst at PKO BP brokerage.
Analysts expected 16,000 points to privide strong support for the WIG index next week.

The main market's WIG index rose 308.1 points, or 1.9 percent, to 16,341.2, and turnover rose 26.6 percent to 205.9 million zlotys ($69.3 million) on both markets as 69 issues rose, eight fell and nine were flat.

Some analysts said the profit-taking correction was likely to be brief and the market could return to its uptrend later on, possibly on growing foreign interest in Polish stocks, which were luring new investors.
Analysts said computer maker Optimus surged 9.6 percent, extending Wednesday's 9.8-percent jump on the back of strong December earnings.
They said construction firm Espebepe's 10-percent rally was speculative, as the firms fundamentals were weak.
Continuous trade turnover was at 20.8 million zlotys ($7 million) with eight stocks rising, seven falling and six staying flat.

Mass privatisaton NFI units fell 1.9 percent to 157 zlotys ($52.8) in 18.2-million-zloty ($6.1 million) continuous trade but rose 2.6 percent in 18.3-million-zloty ($6.2 million) trade in the regular session.
